content: ספיר סבורה שכל מה שניתן להגיד כבר נאמר, לכן על מנת לומר דבר מה בעל חשיבות כל שצריך לעשות הוא לנסח מחדש. אז היא אומרת: ׳יומני היקר; מוריסי היה אבא שלי, האמטיוי היה אמא שלי. בשנת 92 הותירו אותי מולו ולא בדקו מה קורה עם זה במשך חמש עשרה שנה. כבנה הנטוש של מארי אנטואנט, גם אני גדלתי פרא׳. ספיר זורקת שמות. היא מרגישה חיבור עז לעונות השנה, ומחויבות לאביב. היא תוהה אם תפרח בזמן. היא תוהה אם בתור ביתו של מוריסי גם היא היורשת של ביישנות, גסה בצורה נפשעת.

echoes.author: Ecclesiastes (traditional author, Solomon)
echoes.context: This ancient wisdom text expresses a profound sense of the cyclical nature of existence, where human actions and experiences are endlessly repeated.
echoes.text: What has been will be again, what has been done will be done again; there is nothing new under the sun.

echoes.author: Louis XVII (via historical event)
echoes.context: The son of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette, he was separated from his family during the French Revolution and died in prison due to neglect and harsh conditions, his fate a symbol of an innocent life 'grown wild' by abandonment.
echoes.text: Abandoned and left to grow wild in the Temple prison, a tragic consequence of the revolution.

echoes.author: Mary Shelley
echoes.context: As the daughter of radical intellectuals Mary Wollstonecraft and William Godwin, Mary Shelley's identity was profoundly shaped by her unconventional upbringing and the intellectual legacy she inherited and reinterpreted, much like Sapir's self-identification through cultural figures.
echoes.text: The offspring of philosophical and literary giants, crafting narratives of creation and identity.

echoes.author: Ecclesiastes (traditional author, Solomon)
echoes.context: This verse reflects on the natural rhythm of life, emphasizing that there is an appointed time for everything, echoing Sapir's contemplation of 'blooming in time' with the seasons.
echoes.text: To everything there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven.

echoes.author: Walt Whitman
echoes.context: In 'Song of Myself,' Whitman embraces a multifaceted and often contradictory self, a 'multitude' of experiences and traits, resonating with Sapir's query about inheriting conflicting qualities like 'shyness, terribly crude.'
echoes.text: Do I contradict myself? Very well then I contradict myself, (I am large, I contain multitudes.)

echoes.author: Pablo Picasso
echoes.context: This famous quote, often attributed to Picasso, encapsulates the idea that originality in art and thought often comes not from pure invention, but from creatively reinterpreting, 'stealing' from, and re-contextualizing existing ideas, aligning with Sapir's belief in rephrasing as the path to significance.
echoes.text: Good artists copy, great artists steal.

content: על אף האמונה המוצקה בברכותיי,  מצאתי את עצמי נאלצת לספור אותן. חלמתי שאני נכשלת בכל האוניברסיטאות. חלמתי שאני בונה קופסאות קטנות, קטנטנות, פיציות ממש מנייר a4. כל הדיבורים האלו על אלוהים, וחוק, ועוני, רוקנו אותי ממש מתוכן. יצא לי המילוי כמו מכרית ישנה, ונשאר לשכב שם בשמש. בחלום עברתי דרך הגנים למוסד היחיד שניאות לקבלני: המכללה לאדריכלות נוף.

echoes.author: Ecclesiastes
echoes.context: This ancient biblical passage expresses a cyclical view of history and human experience, suggesting that fundamental truths and events recur, making reinterpretation a key to new insight.
echoes.text: What has been will be again, what has been done will be done again; there is nothing new under the sun.

echoes.author: Charles Dickens
echoes.context: The famous plea from the orphan Oliver Twist, embodying the desperate situation of neglected children in Victorian England.
echoes.text: Please, sir, I want some more.

echoes.author: Walt Whitman
echoes.context: Whitman's celebration of the individual self, acknowledging and embracing the vastness and often contradictory nature of human experience and identity.
echoes.text: Do I contradict myself? Very well then I contradict myself, (I am large, I contain multitudes.)

echoes.author: Rainer Maria Rilke
echoes.context: Rilke advises patience and introspection for an aspiring poet, suggesting that answers to deep questions emerge through living experience, akin to a natural blooming process.
echoes.text: Live the questions now. Perhaps you will then gradually, without noticing it, live along some distant day into the answer.

echoes.author: T.S. Eliot
echoes.context: Eliot argues that true originality isn't a rejection of the past, but a re-evaluation and re-ordering of tradition through the new work.
echoes.text: The existing monuments form an ideal order among themselves, which is modified by the introduction of the new (the really new) work of art among them.

echoes.author: Marshall McLuhan
echoes.context: McLuhan theorized that the form of a medium embeds itself in the message, altering how the message is perceived and understood, fundamentally shaping society.
echoes.text: The medium is the message.

content:
ובחלומי שוב לא זכרת את שמי, ונדמה לי שגם אני לא, וצורתך התעוותה מלפניי, וכל החדרים הוצפו, ושוב לא הייתי במקומי.
טיילתי בגנים, זה מדהים אבל כל האנשים היו חברים שלך. גם כשלא דיברו בשבחך, היו חברייך. הם קיבלו את הפגמים האיומים שלך, וכששאלתי, הסתבר שלא היו ככ איומים ממילא.
עליתי במדרגות המטונפות, המלוכלכות, והבית היה מטונף גם כן, אבל המרפסת לא. וכשפניתי ללכת עדיין לא זכרת את שמי, אבל הפעם נדמה לי שניסית להעלות את זכרונו באוב.

*

echoes.author: Jorge Luis Borges
echoes.context: A reflection on identity as a construct of memory, emphasizing its fragmented and often illusory nature.
echoes.text: We are our memory, we are this chimaera of disparate memories.

echoes.author: Gabriel García Márquez
echoes.context: From a novel depicting generations bound by recurring patterns, illustrating the inescapable cycles of family and history.
echoes.text: Families, like nations, have a way of repeating themselves.

echoes.author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
echoes.context: A traveler encounters the ruined statue of an arrogant king, serving as a powerful allegory for the transience of power and the inevitability of decay.
echoes.text: Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair! Nothing beside remains. Round the decay of that colossal Wreck, boundless and bare the lone and level sands stretch far away.

echoes.author: Walt Whitman
echoes.context: A declaration of self-acceptance and the embrace of complexity, suggesting that a rich identity encompasses diverse, even conflicting, aspects.
echoes.text: Do I contradict myself? Very well then I contradict myself, (I am large, I contain multitudes.)

echoes.author: Franz Kafka
echoes.context: The opening line of a novella depicting a man's sudden, inexplicable transformation, leading to profound alienation and a loss of human identity within his own home.
echoes.text: When Gregor Samsa awoke one morning from troubled dreams, he found himself transformed in his bed into a monstrous insect.

echoes.author: Marcel Proust
echoes.context: A core idea from a monumental novel exploring the subjective and often unreliable nature of memory, and how our past is continually reinterpreted.
echoes.text: Remembrance of things past is not necessarily the remembrance of things as they were.

content:
בניגוד למה שנהוג לחשוב, אלוהים לא ישן בשואה; הוא בכה. הוא בכה ובכה ובכה, רעד ממש. 
אלו היו שנים נוראות, אך לא דלות בחסדים. למעשה להיפך. הסביבה העוינת מטבעה לחסד וצדקה הכפילה את ערכו של כל חסד שבעתיים. ולאורך כל הזמן הזה אלוהים לא הפסיק לבכות

echoes.author: Elie Wiesel
echoes.context: Wiesel's harrowing account of his experiences as a prisoner in Auschwitz and Buchenwald during the Holocaust, exploring the depths of human cruelty and the profound questioning of faith and divine presence amidst unimaginable suffering.
echoes.text: Never shall I forget that night, the first night in camp, which has turned my life into one long night, seven times cursed and seven times sealed.

echoes.author: Unknown (Biblical)
echoes.context: The story of Job, a righteous man who endures immense suffering and loss, prompting a profound debate on the nature of divine justice and human resilience in the face of inexplicable adversity and perceived divine neglect.
echoes.text: Naked I came from my mother's womb, and naked I shall return there. The Lord gave and the Lord has taken away. Blessed be the name of the Lord.

echoes.author: Viktor Frankl
echoes.context: Frankl's logotherapy, based on his experiences as a Holocaust survivor, posits that finding meaning in life, even in suffering, is the primary motivational force for humans. He highlighted the importance of acts of kindness and human connection even in the most inhumane conditions, magnifying their value.
echoes.text: Everything can be taken from a man but one thing: the last of the human freedoms—to choose one’s attitude in any given set of circumstances, to choose one’s own way.

echoes.author: Traditionally Jeremiah
echoes.context: A poetic book mourning the destruction of Jerusalem and the First Temple. It vividly describes collective grief, suffering, and the questioning of divine action, reflecting the deep sorrow of a people in exile and resonating with the idea of a shared divine suffering.
echoes.text: My eyes are spent with weeping; my stomach churns; my liver is poured out on the ground because of the destruction of the daughter of my people, because infants and babies are fainting in the streets of the city.

echoes.author: Rabbi Levi Yitzchak of Berditchev
echoes.context: A famous, almost defiant, plea from a Hasidic master to God, challenging divine justice and advocating fiercely for the Jewish people, while simultaneously expressing profound love and faith. It embodies the audacious intimacy and shared suffering often found in Jewish spirituality.
echoes.text: Master of the Universe! I, Levi Yitzchak, son of Sarah, come before You. What do You want from Your people Israel? Why do You persecute them so?

echoes.author: Rabbinic Sages
echoes.context: Various Midrashic texts describe God literally weeping over the destruction of the Temple and the exile of the Jewish people, symbolizing divine empathy and shared grief in the face of national catastrophe. This directly parallels the new entry's imagery of God weeping during the Holocaust.
echoes.text: When the Holy One, Blessed be He, remembered His children who were exiled, He wept, saying, 'Woe is to the father who has banished his children from his table!'
